note.p: Nelson Green Gill was a U.S. soldier, Freedman's Bureau agent, and Republican state Representative for Mississippi during Reconstruction.

Born on November 1, 1830 in Hanover, Oneida County, New York, Gill enlisted in the U.S. Army in the 33rd Illinois Infantry with the outbreak of the Civil War in 1861. He was a member of Comapny B and was discharged carrying a rank of Captain on September 23, 1863.

After the war, Gill relocated to Holly Springs, Marshall County, Mississippi where he served as postmaster and was appointed sheriff. He also joined the Board of Supervisors and served as a Freedman's Bureau agent, taking an active role in promoting Black rights. This work led to at least one assassination attempt on his life. Gill and his wife Martha M. Gill organized a school for Black children in Holly Springs in the 1870s, and he served as Marshall County's Representative to the Mississippi House of Representatives in 1874 and 1875. In 1879, Gill relocated to Kansas, settling near the city of Emporia, where he maintained an active role in local politics, but in 1882 he moved to San Bernardino, California, where he became the county sheriff and was later appointed postmaster.

Gill was married to Martha Minerva "Minnie" (Whitford) Gill. The pair had at least three children, including one boy and two girls. Martha M. Gill applied for a pension on May 5, 1892 in California and is listed as a widow; however, Nelson Green Gill died on October 11, 1903 in San Bernardino, California. He is buried in the Pioneer Memorial Cemetery in San Bernardino.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Holly Springs, MS 1870 Census Record; Martha M. Gill, Pension Application, California, May 5, 1892; Nelson G Gill, U.S. Civil War Soldiers Records and Profiles, 1861-1865)

Richard L. Watson was an attorney and Confederate soldier from Mississippi.

Born on January 12, 1826, in Tennessee, he moved to Mississippi some time before 1860. After the Civil War broke out in 1861, he was commissioned a captain in the Mississippi militia, eventually commanding Company I, Eighteenth Cavalry Battalion. Following the end of the war, Watson practiced law in Holly Springs, Mississippi. In the 1870s, he operated a law firm with Winfield S. Featherston and T. W. Harris. Watson passed away on September 7, 1878, during a yellow fever epidemic.

He was married to Amanda Bradford, who died ten days later during the same epidemic. The couple had at least one child, which died in infancy. Watson is buried at Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.
(FindaGrave; 1860 U.S. Census for Holly Springs, Mississippi, Roll M653_587, Page 160; The Comet, Jackson, MS, December 27, 1879; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, September 25, 1878)

James Thornton Fant was an attorney and judge in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born in Alabama on November 8, 1838, Fant graduated from the University of Mississippi in the late 1850s and became a practicing attorney in Holly Springs, Mississippi. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Fant volunteered for Confederate service and served in the Ninth Mississippi Infantry Regiment. He was promoted to lieutenant in 1862 and was wounded during the Battle of Munfordville, Kentucky, in September 1862.

After the war he was appointed a district attorney and served in that role for several years in the 1870s. Fant also ran a law firm with his brother, Arthur Fant, and established a good reputation for his legal skills. In 1890, he was appointed circuit judge, to fill the vacancy left by the death of William Rogers. He served for two years and then resigned in 1892. He passed away on August 21, 1895. Fant was married to Clara M. Clayton and had at least one child, who died in infancy. Fant is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; Dunbar Rowland, The Official and Statistical Register of the State of Mississippi, 1908, 593; Alfred E. Fant, Fant genealogy, Entry 920; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, March 20, 1878; The Semi-Weekly Leader, Brookhaven, MS, August 14, 1890; The State Ledger, Jackson, MS, September 20, 1892)

Travis Rhodes was a newspaper correspondent and Private Secretary for Mississippi State Governor Adelbert Ames.

His origins are unclear, but by March 1873, Rhodes was living in Jackson, Mississippi and was a correspondent for the Jackson Pilot. A member of the Republican Party, in May 1875, he became Mississippi State Governor Adelbert Ames's Private Secretary. In December that year, he also became a Trustee of the Mississippi State Lunatic Asylum, and he held this position at least through February 1877. In March 1876, Governor Ames resigned. Rhodes continued briefly as the governor's private secretary, but he too resigned at the end of April 1876. After February 1877, his name no longer appeared in Mississippi newspapers regarding political or social activities, and his fate is unclear.

(The Magnolia Gazette, March 28, 1873; The Weekly Mississippi Pilot, May 8, 1875; The Weekly Copiahan, July 1, 1876; The Daily Clarion, December 8, 1875; The Daily Clarion, February 2, 1877; John Snow to the Mississippi Board of Registrars, April 20, 1876, Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, mdah_807-1004-05-17)

Kinloch Falconer was active in Democratic politics in Mississippi during Reconstruction and served as Mississippi’s secretary of state in 1878.

Born on October 28, 1838, Falconer grew up in Holly Springs, Mississippi. As a young man he worked at the Southern Herald (his father’s newspaper) and attended the University of Mississippi, graduating in 1860 on the eve of the Civil War. When the war broke out, Falconer enlisted in the 9th Mississippi Infantry Regiment. Recognized for his intelligence and writing ability, Falconer was soon promoted and moved to administrative and staff work, first serving as the private secretary and then adjutant general for Confederate General Braxton Bragg. Later he served as a staff officer for Confederate General Joseph E. Johnston during the Atlanta Campaign in the summer of 1864.

After the defeat of the Confederacy, Falconer returned to Mississippi and reentered the newspaper business, becoming editor of the Holly Springs Reporter. He began fostering an interest state politics and unsuccessfully ran for lieutenant governor as a Democrat under Benjamin G. Humphreys in 1868. In 1870, Falconer stepped away from editorial duties at the Reporter to practice law full time. He continued participating in Democratic politics and in 1877 was elected secretary of state. He entered that office in January 1878. However, only a few months later, a yellow fever epidemic struck parts of Mississippi. Falconer’s brother and father were stricken by the mosquito-borne disease. He went to Holly Springs to aid in their care, but both men died. Falconer himself then came down with the disease and died on September 23, 1878. He is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.

(The Daily Clarion, Meridian, MS, June 22, 1864; The Grenada Sentinel, Grenada, MS, May 16, 1868; The Clarion, Jackson, MS, February 3, 1870; The. Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, November 6, 1878; Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

Adelbert Ames served as a governor and U.S. senator of Mississippi during the Reconstruction era. He was born in East Thomaston (modern-day Rockland), Maine, in 1835. As a boy, Ames spent time working on various merchant vessels, receiving training in seamanship. He entered the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1856, graduating in May 1861, at the start of the Civil War. Commissioned as a second lieutenant, the young Ames was promoted to first lieutenant barely over a week later and served with the 5th U.S. Artillery during the battle of First Bull Run at Manassas, Virginia, on July 21, 1861. Despite being wounded in the leg, Ames stayed by his cannons. His actions at Bull Run led him to receive the brevet (honorary) rank of major and, in 1893 (more than thirty years later), the Medal of Honor.

Ames recovered from his wound and returned to the front lines in 1862, serving with distinction as an artillery officer during the Peninsula Campaign near Richmond. Seeking better promotion potential, Ames sought an infantry command. Through those efforts, in August 1862, he received command of the 20th Maine Infantry Regiment, and led that unit in combat during the Battle of Fredericksburg in December 1862. In May 1863, he volunteered to serve as a staff officer for Major General George G. Meade, which helped him achieve the rank of brigadier general that month. With this promotion, Ames left the 20th Maine to his second-in-command, Lieutenant Colonel Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain, who gained great fame commanding the regiment at Little Round Top during the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863. Ames’ own performance at Gettysburg was highly praised, as his division successfully defended the Union position at Cemetery Hill.

After Gettysburg, Ames’ division was transferred to the Department of the South. Over the next two years, he commanded Union troops during campaigns in Florida, South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia. He received a brevet promotion to major general for his actions at Fort Fisher, North Carolina, in March 1865.

After the Civil War, Ames became involved in federal Reconstruction efforts. In 1868, he was appointed the provisional governor of Mississippi. Ames proved sympathetic to the plight of African Americans in the south. He sought to protect Black civil rights and appointed Mississippi’s first African American public officials. In 1870, after Mississippi was readmitted into the Union, Ames ran for U.S. senator for the state as a Republican and won. He served in that capacity from February 1870 to January 1874, achieving the reputation as a strong public speaker. While serving as a senator in Washington, D.C., Ames met and married Blanche Butler, daughter of Union general Benjamin F. Butler, under whom Ames had served during the war. Ames and his wife had six children over the course of their marriage.

In 1873, Ames ran for governor of Mississippi. His chief rival was James L. Alcorn, a former Confederate general who had been a Whig before the Civil War and joined the Republican Party afterwards. Ames won the election and worked diligently to improve Mississippi’s financial and social situation. In 1874, Democrats in Mississippi coordinated a campaign of violence against African Americans and white Republicans in the state, to secure political control in Mississippi. Unable to militarily suppress the white supremacist terror campaign, Ames signed a truce with Democratic leaders in Mississippi to reduce the violence and allow a peaceful election. Groups of white supremacists abandoned the truce and resumed their intimidation tactics against Republicans and Black Mississippians during the following elections, leading to a surge of Democratic politicians taking office.

In 1876, the conservative Democrat majority in the Mississippi legislature tried to impeach Ames and many other Republican officials with trumped up charges of corruption. Despite a strong political force against him, Ames’ critics were unable to provide any evidence of impropriety. Nevertheless, because impeachment was politically driven, Ames could see that his future as governor was over and any effort on his part to legally defend himself would be personally and financially taxing. He and his attorneys reached an agreement with Democratic leaders to resign his office in exchange for dropping the legal charges. On March 29, 1876, after Democrats cancelled their legal proceedings, Ames vacated his position.

Ames left Mississippi and went into business in Minnesota with his father and brother. A short time later, he relocated to New York City and then Massachusetts, overseeing mills and various business interests. When the Spanish-American War erupted in 1898, Ames volunteered for service and was appointed brigadier general of volunteers. Although over sixty years old, Ames joined the field campaign in Cuba and performed well.
Ames resumed his business ventures in the early twentieth century. He lived until 1933, dying at age 97. He is buried in Lowell, Massachusetts.
(Wikipedia)

note.p: Winfield Scott Featherston was a U.S. congressman from Mississippi and a general in the Confederate Army during the Civil War.

Born on August 8, 1820, near Murfreesboro, Tennessee, Featherston volunteered for militia service as a teenager during the Second Creek War in Alabama in 1836. After that conflict, he moved to Mississippi and studied law, becoming a practicing attorney in 1840. Soon after, Featherston became involved in local politics, and won a seat to the U.S. House of Representatives for Mississippi in 1846. He served until 1851, then returned to his home in Houston, Mississippi, after losing reelection in 1850. In 1856, he moved to Holly Springs and opened a successful law firm.

Featherston remained a political figure in Mississippi, particularly during the secession movement following Abraham Lincoln’s election to the presidency in 1860. He traveled to Kentucky, as an agent of Mississippi, to encourage secession in that state. When the war broke out in 1861, Featherston received a commission as a colonel and took command of the Seventeenth Mississippi Infantry Regiment. Sent to Virginia, he led Confederate troops at the First Battle of Bull Run and Ball’s Bluff in Virginia. He was promoted to brigadier general in March 1862 and participated in several major engagements that year, including the Seven Days Campaign outside of Richmond, the Second Battle of Bull Run, Antietam, and Fredericksburg.

In early 1863, Featherston was transferred to Mississippi. He commanded a brigade during the Vicksburg campaign, seeing combat at Champion’s Hill, and participated in the Atlanta Campaign in 1864. He remained with General John Bell Hood’s army during the disastrous campaign into Tennessee in late 1864, and commanded a brigade in General Joseph E. Johnston’s army during the final weeks of the war in the Carolinas. He surrendered to Union troops in late April 1865, was paroled shortly afterwards, and returned to Holly Springs, Mississippi.

Featherston immediately returned to politics after the war, running an unsuccessful bid for the United States Senate. He practiced law, and remained active in local political activities opposing Republican Reconstruction. In 1876, he won a seat in the Mississippi legislature and remained there until 1882, when he received an appointment as a district judge. One of his final political acts was as a delegate to Mississippi’s 1890 constitutional convention, which reinstituted many discriminatory policies against African Americans.
Featherston was married to Elizabeth McEwen and had seven children. He died in 1891 and is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Ben Wynne, “Winfield Scott Featherston,” Mississippi Encyclopedia)

Currently located in Marshall County, Holly Springs was founded in 1836 in what was then Monroe County. When Marshall County was created on March 1, 1836, Holly Springs became its county seat. (Rowland, Mississippi, 874; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of the State of Mississippi consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state comptroller, commissioner of agriculture, commissioner of insurance, the Mississippi Public Service Commission, the Mississippi Transportation Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

Occupying about 28 square miles (73 km2) of land, Parchman is the only maximum security prison for men in the state of Mississippi, and is the state's oldest prison." (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: This term refers to the relation, often but not always wives and children, of a person imprisoned in a civilian institution, ranging from jails to penitentiaries.

The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

div.p: To his Excellency, A. Ames, governor of the state of Mississippi

The undersigned citizens of Marshall county, would respectfully represent, that John Mc"Ewin was convicted of grand larceny, at the March term 1875 of the circuit court of the county aforesaid, & sentenced to confinement in the Penitentiary for three years, Where he now is, inpursuance of Said Sentence. His character had been good prior to said charge for which he was so tried, & sentenced. He has a wife & four childen who were dependent on his daily labour for a support. His children are too young to work the oldest being Six, & the youngest only two years old.
In consideration of the premises we ask that he be pardoned for the balance of his term. He has already served eight months. Very respectfully

James A. Scott
